text: (dramatic music)

- [Narrator] They often
have a hand in the game.
They possess unbelievable reactions,
and they decide matches.
- [Announcer] Wow! They saved it.
And that is a fabulous save.
Absolutely spectacular reactions there!

- [Narrator] The goalkeepers
of the Bundesliga.

Finally, there's a Bundesliga
match fact powered by AWS

that accurately measures and
evaluates their performance.
Keeper efficiency.
Keeper efficiency is based
on the so-called xSaves value.
This figure reveals the probability
of a shot on goal being saved.
Like expected goals, xGoals,
each shot is analyzed individually
and compared against historic data.
Unlike the calculation of xGoals,
only attempts that are actually on target
are taken into account.

This is used to calculate
immediately after the finish

how likely it was that
the ball could be saved.
If a goalkeeper saves more shots in a game

than he's statistically
expected to based on xSaves,
he has a positive keeper efficiency;
the mark of a top performance.
To better understand it,

let's look at Frederik
Ronnow's performance
against Frankfurt.
He's one of the reasons why Union Berlin
emerged victorious against Eintracht.
The Eagles had 20 shots on goal,
and according to the goal probability,
could have scored almost three goals.

The fact that didn't
happen is down to Ronnow.

Out of all six of the efforts
that were directly on target,

the xSaves value say he
should have saved four.

But the Dane stopped all six
and kept his team in the game.

So the keeper efficiency
shows that he saved

two more shots than was
statistically expected.
Union Berlin owe the victory, in part,
to Ronnow's excellent performance.

- [Announcer] Daichi Kamada
denied by Frederik Ronnow.

- [Narrator] In the
match against Leverkusen,
Gregor Kobel was instrumental
in ensuring Dortmund's victory.
He faced seven attempts on his goal
and parried all seven with great saves.
At the end of the encounter,
his keeper efficiency stood at 1.2.
In other words, he saved 1.2 shots more
than he should have done
based on the xSaves model

making him the top shot
stopper on that match day.
Rafal Gikiewicz's performance
against Bayern Munich was outstanding
and a crucial factor in Augsburg's win.

The keeper efficiency
of 2.4 demonstrates that

Gikiewicz saved nearly
two and a half shots more
than was statistically expected
from Bayern's attempts on goal.
Another top display.
- [Announcer] Excellent goalkeeping!

Gikiewicz is proving a
source of great frustration
for Bayern so far.

- [Narrator] Of course, there's
more to good goalkeeping

than the number and
quality of shots saved,

and keeper efficiency doesn't
say who the best keeper is.

Shots that go off target
because of, for example,

good positioning like Ronnow's
here against Wolfsburg,

aren't factored into
the calculation at all.
Ronnow plays a significant role

in preventing a goal by
cleverly reducing the angle.
However, this is not included
in the measurement of keeper efficiency
because the ball is not going on target.

The new Bundesliga match
fact keeper efficiency
powered by AWS
recognizes a goalkeeper's performance
and makes it more transparent.
